results.title: Len Lye compilation
results.brief_description:
Includes the following five titles which typify Lye’s technique of directly scratching on the leader and other various techniques directly onto the film.

Tusalava (1929). Lye’s first film was originally accompanied by live music by Jack Ellit. No score was ever found, so the film presented here is silent, a vision of the beginnings of life on earth - mixing Maori, silent and modernist influences.

Rhythm (1957). Live images of a car assembly line lead into Lye’s traditional white scratches, synchronised to African drum music.

Free radicals (1979). Set against African drum music, images are provided by scratches on black leader, created using a variety of tools. Supported by a grant from the New Zealand Film Commission.

Particles in space (1979). New kinds of scratch imagery reflect the disparate element of the title as dots and dashes squiggle about the screen. Supported by a grant from the National Endowment for the Arts. A Federal agency, Washington, D.C

Tal farlow (1980). Jazz guitarist Tal Farlow provides the background music to Lye’s final film, which, although begun in the 50’s, was not recommenced until the 1980’s, only he died before completing it. It contains geometrical scratches and was completed by Lye’s assistant Steve Jones, under the supervision of Ann Lye. Supported in part by a grant from the Queen Elizabeth II Arts Council of New Zealand.

results.title: Tal Farlow
results.brief_description: Jazz guitarist Tal Farlow provides the background music to Lye’s final film, which, although begun in the 1950s, was not recommenced until the 1980s. Unfortunately he died before completing it. It contains vertical white scratches as well as geometric white scratches on black. It was completed by Lye’s assistant Steve Jones under the supervision of Ann Lye. Supported in part by a grant from the Queen Elizabeth II Arts Council of New Zealand.

results.title: Free radicals
results.brief_description:
A primitive kinetic dance of white lines and angles meticulously scratched onto black and white film over an 8 month period and then edited and retrospectively matched with an African field tape of the Bagirmi tribe. The title is a reference to modern physics, ‘free radicals’ being particles of energy. The original version was a major award winner at the Experimental Film Competition at the 1958 Brussels World Fair. This revised version was a reworking of the
original by Lye in 1979, with financial assistance from
the New Zealand Film Commission. He deleted approximately 1 min. from his first version, made in 1958.

group_siblings.title: Rev

results.title: Voyage a travers l'impossible
results.brief_description: Across mountains, under the sea and into the sun, a group of strange travellers attempt an impossible voyage. Exploiting Melies’ mastery of film magic, this early cinema classic explores a vast range of fantasy landscapes. The travellers breach space and time as they travel, using every imaginable means of transportation, from one space and place to another in the attempt to geographically explore the earth and the surrounding space. This extraordinary science fiction fantasy was only one of the many pioneering films made by Melies in the early 1900s and it, like his other films, combines whimsical humour with wild imaginative journeys.

results.title: Le Voyage dans la Lune (A Trip to the Moon)
results.brief_description: Melies’ fantastical vision of life on the moon.

constellations_other.name: Space, sci-fi and cinema fakes
constellations_other.description: Magic lantern slides were used to entertain and educate audiences in home, theatres and universities. While performers told jokes and fairytales, travelling showmen unveiled exotic locations and scientists revealed the latest discoveries.

results.title_for_label: Le Voyage dans la Lune (A Trip to the Moon)
results.description: One of the first Science Fiction films, this Meliesâ€™ short humorously proposes what man discovers when he first lands on the moon. Based on the Jules Verne story, George Melies used his extraordinary cinematic illusions to tell this story of the first voyage to the moon. Made in 1902, this was a visionary film that has come to be recognised as a cinematic masterpiece. Among the many comical set pieces is the famous scene in which a rocket ship crash-lands into the eye of the ‘man in the moon’. This whimsical fantasy is also exemplary in its early depiction of the moon and the possible encounters between humans and worlds beyond our imagining, in our exploration of deep space.

group_siblings.title: L'Eclipse du Soleil en Pleine Lune

results.title: L'Eclipse du Soleil en Pleine Lune
results.brief_description: An aging astronomer invites students to his castle observatory to observe a solar eclipse. Amid the childish pranks of the novice astronomers and the wondrous vision of the eclipse, George Melies, cinema’s great magician, weaves numerous amusing set pieces. Much to the astronomer’s excitement, the sun and the moon flirt with each other as they come together in an astronomical courtship and the sky explodes in a dance of female stars. On earth, the astronomer falls prey to his cheeky students who rob him of his stately dignity, while the heavens smile down on him from above.
